subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Activity 3: Selecting/writing a story

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Before you start making puppets, you should be clear about the story you want to present.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: You can go to the school library and read books to get ideas. Or you can use something you are learning about in other subjects, e.g.,a story or poem from language or a historical event in science or social science. You can also select a story your grandparents tell you. Alternatively, you can think about designing a puppet show around social issues, e.g., Swachh Bharat, polio vaccination or on the rights and responsibilities of citizens.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Remember, you have to make puppets, write a script and put on a show. Therefore, your story must be short and simple, but with some drama and/or action in it.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Activity 4: Writing a script for the puppet show

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: When you see a live performance or watch a film, there are dialogues, changes in scenes, music, action, and many other things. It is much more than just narrating a story. Translating a story into a show is done using a script.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: A script has the step-by-step flow of scenes, dialogues and emotions of the characters. It also contains details, like the position and movement of the puppet(s) during each scene. Elements like short songs or poems, light and sound effects, and so on must be mentioned in the script. The style of speaking has to be made clear, e.g., natural, casual, formal, authoritative, submissive, and so on depending on the character and the scene.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Try and select a story that has at least 2-3 characters. These characters can be animals, humans, aliens — as per the story.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: To help you understand how to write the script, an example of a story called ‘Gopal and the Hilsa Fish’ is given in Table 5.2. This story is about a king who does not like people talking about the Hilsa fish in the court. He challenges Gopal, his courtier, to buy a huge Hilsa fish and bring it to the palace without anyone talking about it. Gopal accepts the challenge. He shaves half his beard and smears ash on himself. People are so surprised by his appearance that they do not talk about the big Hilsa fish in his hand.

These are known as characteristics. Deciding the characteristics of your puppet is known as making a character sketch. subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Using graph paper makes drawing easier

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Suppose, your story has a rabbit. You can draw a rabbit on paper and paste it on cardboard. You can then attach a stick to the cardboard to move your rabbit puppet.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: To draw the rabbit, take a picture of a rabbit, tracing paper and graph paper.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Draw the rabbit on the tracing paper and paste it on the graph paper. Next, draw lines proportionate to the graph on the chart paper you want to draw the rabbit on - this will help you make a larger rabbit. You can now copy each part of the rabbit onto the chart paper. Erase the lines once you are done and colour your rabbit (Figure 5.6). Once the stick is pasted to the body of the rabbit, your puppet is ready.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Activity 6: Making puppets

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: You can make puppets with materials available around you - clay, soft wood, grass, wastepaper, used bottles, thermocol, cardboard or any other suitable material. For example, you can stick cutouts of fish drawn on chart paper around a broomstick and move them to narrate a simple story set in the sea. You can stick a piece of chart paper around a broomstick and then paste nose, eyes, ears made of chart paper or of materials like wool.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Some examples of materials and objects that you can use to create puppets are given in figures 5.7 to 5.13. Do try out other materials and see what you can do.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Voice

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Voice modulation plays an extremely powerful role in puppetry; the puppeteer acts through her or his voice. You must assign distinct voices to each puppet to differentiate the characters. For example, a lion puppet could have a deep, commanding voice, while a rabbit could have a high- pitched, playful voice.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: To make sure the audience understands what you are saying, speak clearly and loudly. Practice showing emotions, like happiness, fear, or excitement using voice

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Sound and music

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: You should have different types of sounds in the puppet show depending on the script —- background music or sounds effects, like thundering of clouds before rain. You can use musical instruments or create sounds by tapping on the floor or the desk using a pencil, scale or your fingers. You can tap on a glass or bottle with different levels of water to create music for your show. You can experiment with different sound effect using the sound system; for example, whistling into a microphone creates the sound of the wind (Figure 5.26).

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Refer to your script (Table 5.3) to decide lighting effects and how you will generate them.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Puppeteer

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: The puppeteer needs to rehearse the dialogues well. Remember, the puppet is speaking, not you. You should also know when the puppet will enter the stage— ‘in’ and when to exit the stage — ‘out’.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Secondly, the puppeteer should look at the puppet while the puppet talks to the audience. This means that as a puppeteer your face needs to be flat without emotions, so that the audience looks at the puppet and not at you.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: aryl) Project 6 : Family Health Handbook

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: This project will help you learn about maintaining the health and well-being of your family. You will create a family health handbook and identify actions to improve the health of your family.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: As part of the project, you will be able to:

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Iden tj impo, f2etors Recorg health alyse h

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: YOGA for LIFE

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Figure 6.1: Maintaining health and well-being is essential for all of us

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Ch-6 Famly Health Handbook.indd 138

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Family health refers to the overall physical, mental, and emotional well-being of all members within a family. The health of individuals and the family as a whole are interconnected with each other.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Good health results from many factors, including diet, physical fitness, sleep, mental well-being, and environmental factors (Figure 6.1). While all these factors are important for people of different ages, the needs of people from various age groups are different. This project is about understanding the needs of different members of the family and creating a family health handbook.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: You have learnt about the importance of health both in school, and from family and friends. You are also aware that good health, a positive attitude and mental well-being are very important for your happiness. You may have been practicing Yoga and found that it helps you not only to be physically fit but also to be calm and energised throughout the day. You become more flexible and stronger while being able to concentrate on whatever you are doing.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: You have also learnt that a nutritious and well-balanced diet is necessary to meet the body’s needs. Different components of food are necessary to fulfil different needs of the body, and give us energy to work and play.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: In addition to this, rest is very important. Our body repairs itself when we sleep, and we wake up refreshed and ready for another day. Depending on age, sleeping for a certain number of hours daily is, therefore, very important for health.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Positive attitude and mental well-being are equally important. A well-balanced diet, regular exercise, personal hygiene, positive thoughts, and kindness are important for mental well-being. Along with these, it is important to do things you enjoy and to spend time with loved ones.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Still, despite all these efforts, people fall ill due to various reasons, including environmental factors. Therefore, you need to take care to protect yourself and your family. For example, timely vaccination, taking precautions to prevent spread of infections, keeping the surroundings clean, and ensuring there is no stagnant

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Family Health Handbook

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Ch-6 Famly Health Handbook.indd 139 18-03-2025 4.28.52 PM.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: water where mosquitoes can breed. Knowing whom to ask for help and when to see the doctor is also important.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Thus, essential factors for assuring health are —- well-balanced and nutritious diet, physical fitness, sleep, positive attitude and mental well-being, and environmental factors.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: In this project, you will learn more about these factors and what can be done to maintain your health and that of your family. You will develop and maintain records and write your action plan in the family health handbook.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: io, By the end of this project, you will be able to: 1. Identify the specific needs of individuals of different age groups. 2. Respond to any health issue in the family. 3. Create a first-aid kit for use in school and at home. 4. Develop a plan to support good health and well-being in the family.

text: During visits to the hospital/ Primary Health Centre (PHC)/ Community Health Centre (CHC), maintain your distance and wear a mask to protect yourself and the patients. Remember to wash your hands thoroughly after the visit. Dispose of used gloves, masks and bandages as directed by the expert and/or your Teacher to prevent the spread of infection. Be sensitive and empathetic to the injured, young children and the old. Accept diversity—do not judge people by body shapes, sizes, or food habits.

text: Which factors can you do something about, and which are out

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: of your control?

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Did you know?

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: These are some recommendations by health experts.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Diet and Nutrition

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Meal Frequency: Eating three main meals and 1-2 healthy snacks at consistent intervals prevents overeating or dips in energy. Hydration: Drinking at least 6-8 glasses of water daily is essential for digestion, temperature regulation, and mental focus.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Eat home cooked food and limit eating processed food: Even a ‘simple meal’ like dal fry and rice ordered from outside may not be healthy since you are unsure of the amount of oil added or whether the dal is freshly cooked or stale. Therefore, limiting food ordered from outside, processed snacks (e.g., chips), sugary drinks, and fried foods is good for health.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Sleep Pattern

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Sleep duration varies by age. Ideally, about 9-11 hours of sleep is ideal for students aged 6-13, while about 8-9 hours of sleep is sufficient for adults. Children below the age of 5 require more than 11 hours of sleep.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: . Healthy body functioning is also determined by a regular sleep

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: schedule (going to bed and waking up at the same time daily); this helps regulate the body’s internal clock.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: . Disruptions like noise, bright lights, or uncomfortable bedding

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: can affect sleep patterns.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: . To go to sleep easily, avoid stimulating activities, like screen time,

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: loud music, or heavy meals an hour before sleep.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Physical Fitness

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Lack of physical activity and a sedentary lifestyle can have a very harmful effect on body functions in the long run.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Consistency is key, so you should choose a physical activity that you like. It can be yoga, sports or a simple walk.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Kaushal Bodh— Grade 7

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Ch-6 Famly Health Handbook.indd 142

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Mental Well-being

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Just as our physical well-being can be affected by many factors, our mental well-being is also prone to being affected. For example, due to a fight with a friend, examination stress, concerns about family, or any other reason. Mental and physical well-being are interconnected, and both are equally important. Spending time with friends and family, and on productive activities, including games and sports, helps maintain mental well-being.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: You have identified factors that affect health and may have noted some questions. As you continue to work on your project, you will try and find answers to these questions. You will understand the needs of persons of different age groups and identify environmental factors around you that may affect health. You will also learn how to provide first-aid, and how to avail medical care. Finally, you will come up with an action plan to improve and maintain your and your family’s health. All this will be part of your family health handbook.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: You can learn more about family health and first-aid techniques by searching on the Internet.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: You can search using keywords, like family health, basic first-aid and steps, tips for family health and wellness, first-aid for common injuries, etc.

text: Activity 2: Framing questions related to your and your family’s health

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Activity 4: Creating a first-aid kit

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Once you have observed and understood the use of the first-aid kit at the centre, you can create it on your own in school.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: In our daily lives, we often experience minor cuts, accidents, wounds, and minor illness. A first-aid kit can provide medical assistance. It is equipped with basic medicines for emergencies. You should also have a first-aid kit at home as a part of your safety readiness plan.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: The first-aid activities you could focus on are:

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. Tying bandages for minor cuts (Figure 6.3).

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. First-aid for minor burns (Figure 6.4).

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. Preparing ORS during dehydration (Figure 6.5).

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Remember, first-aid is only emergency treatment before you take the patient to the doctor.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. Discussion on the importance ofa first-aid kit to treat basic ailments.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. Exploring components of the first-aid kit: Decide the contents that can be incorporated into the school first-aid kit. Brainstorm on possible injuries and health issues which might occur on school premises and what components will be required.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. Organising and labelling the components of the first-aid kit.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 4. Making the first-aid kit: The components you have selected must be placed in a wide metal container or a small bag with pockets. You may make separators using cardboard or place the components in smaller boxes or bags to ensure you can find them easily, if needed. The box or bag must have the label ‘first-aid kit’.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 5. Demonstration and practice of use: Make notes while experts demonstrate basic procedures, such as applying bandages for cuts, treating minor burns, dehydration, fever, etc.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 6. Deciding where to place the first-aid kit: The first-aid kit should be kept in an easily accessible place on the school premises, but out of reach of the younger students.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Activity 5: Factors affecting health at different ages

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: People have different needs at different ages. You may have noticed that babies eat and sleep a lot, and elderly people like to rest in the afternoon. To identify specific needs of your family members, you must understand the factors affecting health at different ages.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Each family is different, e.g., some families have parents and one or more children, some are joint families with many generations living in the same house, some are only made up of one parent and a child - many variations are possible. However, most of us will have people of all ages in our extended families, or family friends of different ages.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: With this in mind, collect and document basic health data and some observations related to daily routine for the following age groups: (i) Below 5 years, (ii) 6-18 years, (iii) 19-30 years, (iv) 31-45 years, (v) 46-60 years, (vi) above 60 years. Even if you do not have a family member from any of these age groups, you can collect information from a relative/neighbour/friend. You can make separate sections for every age group using 3-4 sheets, or as required, for each member in your handbook.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Testing quality of potable water

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Clean drinking water is essential for good health. Contaminated water can lead to diseases, like diarrhoea, cholera, typhoid, and other long-term health problems. Testing the quality of water helps

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Kaushal Bodh— Grade 7

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Ch-6 Famly Health Handbook.indd 152

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: to ensure that it is safe to drink; this can protect your family from harmful illnesses.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: It is very easy to test if water is potable. The H2S Strip Test Kit is a simple method used to check for bacterial contamination in water.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Using HS strip test kit

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. Pour the water sample into the bottle up to the given mark (20 ml).

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. Cap the bottle and mix well. The colour of the water will change to golden brown.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. Keep this bottle at room temperature (about 25-35°C ). In case of low temperatures, the bottle should be wrapped in a warm cloth and kept in a warm place.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 4. Do not disturb the bottle for 24-28 hours.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 5. Now observe the colour of the sample (Figure 6.7).

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Interpreting test

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. If the colour does not change and remains golden brown: Water is safe for drinking.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. If the colour turns black: Water is contaminated with harmful bacteria and is not safe for drinking.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 48 hrs Safe to use Unsafe to use

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: ») ( Figure 6.7: H,S test

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: If you find water is not safe for drinking, inform those using this water about potential danger, e.g., you can paint a poster and put it near the water source.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Discuss the results with your Teacher and elder members of the family and learn how to clean water before drinking.

text: Did you know?

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Malaria is one of the major health problems in our country. It is caused by the bite of an infected female Anopheles mosquito. However, there is a simple solution to preventing Malaria — using mosquito nets reduces the cases of Malaria by preventing mosquito bites.

text: You may have shared something with other students and teachers during classroom presentations or during school assembly. You can also invite your family and other people to come and see your work. You can do this through the Kaushal Mela. But first, you must plan each detail carefully.

text: Planning is important since it helps you decide how to reach your goal. You must think about what need to be done and when it needs to be done so that everything goes smoothly. For example, if you are putting up a puppet show, you need to decide when and where keeping in mind that the maximum number of people watch it. Planning also helps to prevent wastage of time and resources. For example, if you want to demonstrate the tie and dye process, you must ensure all the materials are available in one place in the right quantity.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Since the Kaushal Mela will involve a lot of planning and coordination, you must plan each detail carefully. Responsibilities must be assigned for each activity, and the process for each activity discussed in detail. You must also develop a plan to work together as a team.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Project Template

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Developing effective projects in schools require careful planning, clear objectives, and engaging activities that align with educational goals.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: The diagram given below summarises the key questions that need to be addressed while developing the project.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Name and brief introduction of the project

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Choose a title that is descriptive and engaging, and gives a clear idea of the broad purpose of the project.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Explain why the project is important.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Highlight its relevance to the students’ lives, education, or the community.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Discuss the benefits of the project.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Describe how the project relates to real-world scenarios, tasks or problems.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Explain the practical implications and potential impact of the project.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Ch-8 Annexures.indd 164

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Achievable and measurable objectives aligned with the curricular goal, competencies and grade-wise learning outcomes have to be defined for each project. Activities must be designed for the fulfilment of these objectives. Define two or three simple objectives in words that students can understand. These objectives indicate what students will be able to do at the end of the project. Students must be able to respond to the following questions: 1. What will you be able to do by the end of the project? 2. What will you learn?

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: What will I need?

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Ensure that the required resources are accessible and locally available, and help students identify what is required for the project. Students must be able to: 1. Provide a brief overview of the tools, equipment, materials, and other resources needed for the project.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: This section should include all the safety precautions to be taken during the project, including Internet safety measures. Students should also wear appropriate clothing, such as long sleeves, pants, and sturdy shoes, while doing activities in the field.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Safety precautions related to tools, materials, equipment, and internet use must be explained and demonstrated. Students must be able to respond to the following questions:

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. Howwill you ensure your safety and that of others during the project?

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. What will you do to ensure no one is physically or emotionally hurt?

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. How will you ensure the safety of plants and animals, if relevant?

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 4. How will you maintain confidentiality (that is, you will not share

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: information about anyone without checking with them first)?

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 5. What will you do to keep yourself safe on the Internet?

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Annexure 1

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Ch-8 Annexures.indd 165 18-03-2025 4.33.47 PM.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: (4 What do I need to know before I start?

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Prepare students to begin work by recalling prior knowledge, introducing concepts through activities that require them to work with tools and materials, exploring the environment and basic skills related to the project, and so on. Clearly define roles and responsibilities for all participants, and ensure everyone understands their tasks and how they contribute to the project. Students must be able to respond to the following questions: 1. Is there anything you need to learn before starting your project? 2. Do you need to meet an expert who can teach you how to do the activities related to the project? 3. Is there anything in your locality that you need to find out about? 4. Do you need to conduct a survey, take up field visits, or something similar before you start?

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Students need to take up various activities required for the completion of the project. Frame questions that will help them to think about what is to be done, and subsequently, record data or information related to the project. Students must be able to do the following: 1. Follow the project plan and execute tasks according to the timelines. 2. Observe others to learn practical skills and techniques, such as proper tool usage, effective planting methods, and maintenance practices. 3. Monitor progress regularly and adjust as necessary. 4. Keeprecords ofall activities and challenges faced during the activities. 5. Document what they have learnt, their successes and challenges for future reference. As they complete each activity, students can be asked the following: 1. The materials you used and how you used them. 2. The tools you used and how you used them. 3. The process you followed, such as the selection of materials/tools, sequence of tasks, and how you completed each one. 4. Ifyou collected information/data/objects, describe them and explain why they are useful. If you made something, include a photograph or a sketch. If you grew a plant, record its growth. What safety precautions did you take while doing the activities? Did you use any AI tool? If yes, which ones did you use and how did you use them? 9. Did you share the outcome of your project with others outside the school? Describe your plan and how you executed it. 10. Did you do something to keep the environment clean or to recycle waste? Record the details.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Ch-8 Annexures.indd 166

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Learning from others is a crucial aspect of any project. Therefore, students should reflect on what they have learnt from others. It can help improve their soft skills, deepen their understanding, and enhance the project’s overall success.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Engaging with others enables students to communicate effectively, share ideas, and collaborate on tasks. Diverse perspectives and ideas are introduced, which help students learn from the viewpoints of others. This can help them approach problems in new ways, and enhance their creativity and problem- solving skills. Listening to others, such as workers in the world of work, experts, professionals, and the like provides valuable insights that can help improve learner’s practices.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Students must be able to identify what they learnt during field trips, online and offline interactions with experts, from family and friends, community members, and other sources. They must be able to respond to the following

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: questions: 1. What did you learn from field trips, interactions, video lectures, or experts? 2. What did you learn from your friends? Did you help them with something? 3. What did you learn from family members, siblings, and community elders?

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 4. What did you learn from people in the community?

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: What did I do and how long did it take?

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: In order to develop the capacity for time-based planning, students must record the entire process followed, the sequence of activities, and the time taken for each activity. This can be done as they proceed or at the end of the project. Students must be able to respond or think back on what they did and how long it took them to plan and execute the activities.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Ori Ma What else can I do?

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Students need to think of other setting, in which they can apply their learning from the projects, especially outside the school. For example, students can participate in workshops, coding classes, and exhibitions or fairs. They can

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Annexure 1

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Ch-8 Annexures.indd 167 18-03-2025 4.33.47 PM.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: also apply their learnings from the projects at home, and in various other places. They can celebrate cultural heritage months, international days, or multicultural festivals, and organise cultural events, culinary events, skill exhibitions, etc. They can integrate subjects through interdisciplinary projects, like historical re-enactments, science and art collaborations, or literary functions through performances.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Students must be able to respond to the following questions:

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. What else can you do to apply your learning from the project?

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. Do you see any scope to expand the current project? How?

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Students must reflect on what they have learned from their recent experiences. A set of questions must be designed to assess learning of key aspects of the project and related concepts across curricular areas.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Some of the questions that can be asked include the following:

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. What did you enjoy doing? What were the challenges you faced? Question(s) related to the project itself. What are some examples of jobs related to the activities you just did? What other jobs are related to the project?

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Planning

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Since planning is animportant part ofall work, all projects contain components of planning. However, to ensure students are able to detail out the steps required in planning, the planning section can be used as it is given in the Activity Book. In case the school plans an alternative approach to meet this outcome, it must be ensured that students are able to respond to the following questions:

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. What is the final event you are planning? When and where will it be held? Who will be the invitees? What will the final event involve? What are the steps required to ensure the final event goes as per the plan, and when do they have to be fulfilled? What are the resources involved and who will be responsible for each step?

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: ANNEXURE 4

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Time Allocation and Mapping of Learning Outcomes

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: The tables given ahead indicate Time Allocation and Mapping of Learning Outcomes for the activities included in the projects for Grade 7.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Time Allocation: The time allocated for each activity is a suggestion, and teachers can adjust it based on their class size and complexity of the project.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Cross-curricular Connections: The projects can be drawn from other subjects in the Middle Stage—Language, Mathematics, Science, Social Science, Art Education, and Physical Education and Well-being. This allows for a more holistic learning experience. Connection to other curricular areas is also indicated in the upcoming tables.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Student Reflection: Reflection prompts are included (“What did I learn?”, “What else can I do?”) to encourage students to think critically about their work.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Safety: The tables emphasise safety precautions (LO 6) for activities involving tools or potential hazards.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Open-ended Learning: The “What else can I do?” section (LO 16) encourages students to explore connect to home and extend their learning.

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Learning Outcomes: Each project focuses on developing specific skills and knowledge (LO 1-9) along with essential values related to work (LO 10-15).

subject: VOCATIONAL_EDUCATION
text: Please note that LO 10 to LO 15, which refer to the essential values while working across areas, are applicable across all activities.
